Description: Limestone tomb-relief of Nyibunesu: the slab bears a figure in strong, well-moulded low relief of Nyibunesu, shown wearing full official dress including a leopard-skin kilt. In front is a line of text with his name and titles. There are remains of black paint on the wig and on the armlet of the pendant arm and of red paint on the band across the chest.
Curator's comments: This slab was found by Petrie in the tomb of Nyibunesu, at Dendera; it was placed in the innermost recess of the false door, above the tomb relief (1898,0817.11); there were no other texts or representations, cf. W. M. F. Petrie, 'Dendereh' (London, 1900), pl. 2. The date of the tomb is by no means certain; it could be earlier than the Fourth Dynasty, but would then be an almost isolated example of very early tomb-sculpture from the necropolis of Dendera. Bibliography: B. Porter & R. Moss, 'Topographical Bibliography of Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts, Reliefs and Paintings' V (Oxford: Clarendon Press), p. 110.
Bibliographic references: James 1961 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc. Part 1 (pl.12)
Condition: Fair. The hole that pierces the slab in front of the face was there when the tomb was discovered.
